UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES
RAPSKE ET AL.
NOT FORGIVEN, NOT FORGOTTEN:
AN INVESTIGATION OF UNFORGIVEN
INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES
DEBRA L. RAPSKE, SUSAN D. BOON, ALISHIA M. ALIBHAI,
AND MEGAN J. KHEONG
University of Calgary
Despite valuable lessons that may be learned about forgiveness from studying
instances when people do not forgive, few investigations have directly targeted
unforgiven offenses. The present study extends the literature on forgiveness by
analyzing responses to open-ended questions in which 185 participants dis-
cussed interpersonal offenses they had not forgiven, explained why they did not
forgive, and identied advantages and disadvantages of not forgiving. Unforgiven
episodes varied substantially in type and severity, suggesting that people differ in
their forgiveness thresholds. Additionally, analysis of participants’ explanations
for not forgiving highlighted the possibility that beliefs about forgiveness may
sometimes impede forgiveness. Finally, most participants reported both costs and
benets associated with not forgiving. Implications for conceptualizing forgive-
ness and implementing forgiveness interventions are discussed.
Despite a burgeoning literature on forgiveness, the systematic study
of situations in which individuals do not forgive is in its infancy.
The present study sought to build on the relatively small body of
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1101
knowledge in this area by exploring answers to three related re-
search questions concerning unforgiven interpersonal episodes:
What kinds of acts and events do people report when asked to de-
scribe incidents they have not forgiven? What explanations do they
offer to justify their inability or unwillingness to forgive? And what
do they identify as the key advantages and disadvantages associ-
ated with not forgiving?
As we all know, people do not always respond to interpersonal
offenses by forgiving those who harm them. Sometimes they fail in
their efforts to bring about the difﬁcult transformation of thought
and feeling that forgiveness requires. In their hearts or minds they
may be unable to come to terms with the pain they have endured,
incapable of seeing the transgressor without experiencing a ﬂood
of anger and bitterness, or unable to stop wishing that the offender
be made to suffer as they have. Sometimes they are uninterested
in taking the steps necessary to produce such change, believing in-
stead that the offender deserves their continuing wrath or that the
anguish they experienced or indignity they sustained is too great to
justify any reckoning that would require that they abandon claims
for sympathy and desires for retribution. Sometimes the offender
continues to act in ways that, for all but the most generous of souls,
preclude the possibility of giving forgiveness serious consider-
ation.
Consistent with such reasoning, Worthington (2001) has argued
that forgiving is just one of several means by which individuals
seek to reduce the unpleasant complex of negative emotions that
typically arises when they experience harm or offense at the hands
of another. Other responses exist, as research on accommodation
(Rusbult, Verette, Whitney, Slovik, & Lipkus, 1991) and revenge
(Boon, Deveau, & Alibhai, 2009; McCullough, 2008; Yoshimura,
2002, 2007) and theorizing on grudge holding (Baumeister, Exline,
& Sommer, 1998; Exline & Baumeister, 2001) attests. A full under-
standing of how people respond to interpersonal offenses will thus
require a detailed examination of interpersonal episodes that do not
end in forgiveness.
People also differ with respect to whether they view forgiveness
as universally appropriate, desirable, or possible. Jewish theology,
for example, identiﬁes certain offenses (e.g., very severe offenses
such as heresy and murder, offenses committed by those who are
unrepentant, and any offense for which one is not the victim) as un-
forgivable (Cohen, Malka, Rozin, & Cherfas, 2006), therefore legiti-
1102 RAPSKE ET AL.
mizing the decision to withhold forgiveness under certain circum-
stances. Other research (Macaskill, 2005a) suggests that the belief
that forgiveness is a bounded phenomenon extends to non-Jewish
populations and cuts across both religious and secular lines: When
Macaskill asked her British participants whether there are limits to
forgiveness, nearly 70% of non church-attending, 50% of church-
attending, and 34.1% of clergy-member participants answered in
the afﬁrmative. Such variation in the extent to which people con-
sider forgiving an appealing, legitimate, and moral venture in the
aftermath of interpersonal injury or offense provides an important
impetus for exploring in depth those instances in which they cannot
or will not forgive.
Finally, there may be much to learn about forgiving from investi-
gating when people do not forgive. In the same way that the study
of visual illusions in perception and errors and biases in cognitive
processing have enabled richer understandings of the processes of
accurate perception and social inference (cf., Nisbett & Ross, 1980),
investigations of instances in which things go wrong so that people
are unable or unwilling to forgive an interpersonal harm may pro-
vide important insights concerning what it takes for things to go
right so that people can forgive. In addition to enhancing our under-
standing of the processes involved in forgiving, such insights could
facilitate the design of interventions aimed at promoting forgive-
ness among those who wish to forgive, while simultaneously en-
riching people’s awareness of the complexities involved in obtain-
ing forgiveness from those they have harmed (e.g., by highlighting
the kinds of concerns that might diminish their victim’s motivation
to forgive).
As part of a larger questionnaire, participants in the present study
described an unforgiven interpersonal offense. Here we report on
their responses to four open-ended questions concerning (a) the of-
fenses they recalled, (b) the reasons they withheld forgiveness, and
(c) their beliefs concerning the advantages and disadvantages of not
forgiving. As Reis (2007) has argued, descriptive work of this sort
serves an important purpose in laying the groundwork for theo-
retical development. The present analysis thus constitutes an im-
portant initial step in generating a descriptive base concerning key
parameters of unforgiven offenses, useful both as a foundation for
extending and reﬁning theory on forgiveness and as a point of de-
parture for future investigations of people’s experiences in relation
to unforgiven interpersonal episodes.
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1103
UNFORGIVEN OFFENSES
Three research questions guided the present analysis. The ﬁrst
sought to expand our understanding of the nature and scope of un-
forgiven offenses. Research suggests that there are limits to the kinds
of offenses and injuries people are willing and able to forgive (Ma-
caskill, 2005a; Younger, Piferi, Jobe, & Lawler, 2004). For example,
acts such as sexual assault, sexual abuse, and murder are typically
perceived to cross the line between what is and is not forgivable.
Most people never experience violent crimes, however, and still they
do not always forgive those who cause them harm or offense. The
fact that people sometimes withhold forgiveness in response to less
extreme, more mundane wrongdoings warrants an examination of
the nature of unforgiven—though not necessarily unforgivable—
offenses. Investigations that directly target unforgiven offenses are
nevertheless uncommon in the literature and, even among those
rare investigations that do (e.g., Younger et al., 2004; Zechmeister
& Romero, 2002), researchers have not yet focused their attention
on cataloguing the kinds of wrongdoings that remain unforgiven. If
we hope someday to establish what, if anything, sets unforgiven of-
fenses apart from forgiven offenses, we must redress this important
gap in the literature.
EXPLANATIONS FOR WITHHOLDING FORGIVENESS
Our second research question examined the justiﬁcations people of-
fer to explain their unwillingness or inability to forgive. Like the
nature of unforgiven offenses, this, too, is an issue that has gone
largely unexplored to date. Our literature review identiﬁed just one
published study investigating the reasons people give to account
for not forgiving (Younger et al., 2004), a second published study on
factors that make forgiving difﬁcult (Williamson & Gonzales, 2007),
and two articles on grudge theory (Baumeister et al., 1998; Exline
& Baumeister, 2001) that point to barriers to forgiveness. This small
body of work suggests that people attribute their refusal to forgive/
difﬁculty forgiving to a number of causes including an offender’s
failure to apologize or express remorse, beliefs that the offender
does not deserve forgiveness, strong feelings about the morality of
the offense (i.e., believing it to be unforgivable), lingering hurt and
anger and, when the offender continues to act in hurtful ways, the
1104 RAPSKE ET AL.
ongoing nature of the offense. More generally, it shows that people
often ﬁnd severe offenses, intentionally harmful offenses, and of-
fenses involving breaches of relational roles or obligations difﬁcult
to forgive.
An intriguing possibility suggested by this review of previous
research is that people’s understandings of forgiveness may some-
times impede forgiving. Though not directed speciﬁcally at examin-
ing people’s explanations for withholding forgiveness, the literature
on lay understandings of forgiveness appears to corroborate this
speculation: People often conceptualize forgiveness in conditional
terms, believing it to be contingent on the satisfaction of certain con-
straints. The majority of participants in Macaskill‘s (2005a) study, for
example, reported that forgiveness is only possible if (a) the victim
is willing to compromise and able to understand the motivations
and other causal forces behind the offender’s actions and (b) the
offender apologizes, expresses signs of remorse, and demonstrates
desires for reconciliation. More generally, research shows that many
people perceive repentance as a necessary precursor to forgiveness
(Exline & Baumeister, 2001; Kanz, 2000; Kearns & Fincham, 2004;
Williamson & Gonzales, 2007; Younger et al., 2004) and believe that
real forgiveness is impossible unless the victim is willing to seek
renewed contact and a continuing relationship with the offender
(Kanz, 2000). Such beliefs may prove potent obstacles to forgiving.
In sum, few scholars have devoted their efforts directly to the in-
vestigation of the reasons people give to explain withholding for-
giveness from those who have injured or offended them. We sought
here to replicate and extend Younger et al.’s ﬁndings by examining
people’s justiﬁcations for not forgiving and, in particular, the role
that beliefs about forgiveness may play in their accounts.
ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES OF
WITHHOLDING FORGIVENESS
Our ﬁnal research question explored people’s perceptions of the
costs and beneﬁts associated with not forgiving. To our knowledge,
this topic has not been examined empirically to date, although
grudge theory (Baumeister et al., 1998; Exline & Baumeister, 2001)
considers the advantages and disadvantages of withholding for-
giveness in some depth.
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1105
According to grudge theory, people perceive two main beneﬁts
to holding a grudge. First, holding a grudge confers a measure of
protection against future victimization by helping to prevent recur-
rence. Second, it enables wronged individuals to maintain the vic-
tim role and thereby continue to reap its associated beneﬁts, which
include the ability to justify continuing experiences and/or expres-
sions of feelings such as anger, righteous indignation, and moral
superiority. Such feelings may promote a sense of personal power
in relation to the offender and elicit others’ sympathy and support
(Exline & Baumeister, 2001).
On the down side, grudge theory posits that holding a grudge
can trap wronged individuals in the victim role, a role that—despite
its beneﬁts—is often associated with suffering, weakness, passivity,
and misfortune (Baumeister et al., 1998). Because it means remain-
ing a victim, then, withholding forgiveness may be associated with
enduring emotional distress and reduced functioning, especially in
interpersonal relations.
In addition to the costs that grudge theory outlines, there are rea-
sons to believe that people may view withholding forgiveness as
detrimental to their health. A substantial minority of participants in
Younger et al.’s (2004) study justiﬁed having forgiven with explana-
tions implying that forgiving was good for their mental and physi-
cal wellbeing. If, as research suggests, these individuals’ beliefs are
valid and forgiveness does, indeed, promote the health of body,
mind, and relationships (e.g., Bono, McCullough, & Root, 2008;
Lawler-Row, Karremans, Scott, Edlis-Matityahou, & Edwards, 2008;
Witvliet, Ludwig, & Vander Laan, 2001), failing to forgive may pose
a signiﬁcant threat to health and wellbeing. Consistent with this
proposition and based on research on the hostility/anger-health link
(Barefoot, Dahlstrom, & Williams, 1983; Siegel, 1992), Rye, Folck,
Heim, Olszewski, and Traina (2004) argue that prolonged grudge
holding may cause both physical and emotional problems.
Individuals’ beliefs and experiences concerning the costs and
beneﬁts associated with not forgiving may play a formative role
in determining whether they consider forgiving a reasonable and
viable alternative in response to injury or offense. There is thus a
considerable need for research exploring people’s perspectives on
the real and perceived consequences associated with maintaining a
nonforgiving stance toward an offender. The present study consti-
tutes the ﬁrst empirical investigation to address this need.
1106 RAPSKE ET AL.
In sum, the present study seeks answers to three research ques-
tions that have been largely neglected to date. In providing answers
to these questions, this study extends the forgiveness literature by
broadening our understanding of the nature and scope of unfor-
given interpersonal offenses (particularly with respect to the more
mundane, everyday variety of offenses), expanding our knowledge
of the range and type of justiﬁcations people use to explain their
inability/unwillingness to forgive, and investigating the advan-
tages and disadvantages people believe to be associated with not
forgiving, an issue that has received only theoretical consideration
to date.
METHOD
PARTICIPANTS
Undergraduate psychology students (165 females and 24 males) at
a large university in western Canada received partial course credit
for completing an online questionnaire about an interpersonal of-
fense they had not forgiven. We dropped the data for three female
participants who reported that they had forgiven their offenders
and for one male participant who identiﬁed himself as his offender.
Participants in the ﬁnal sample (N = 185, 162 females and 23 males)
ranged in age from 18 to 53 (M = 22.76, SD = 5.47). The majority
(71.9%) self-identiﬁed as European or Caucasian, 21.1% reported
Asian ancestry, and 5.9% reported multiple ethnicities (two partici-
pants did not respond to the ethnicity item).
PROCEDURE
Participants were recruited online via a brief ad on the Department
of Psychology research webpage. Posted eligibility criteria required
that participants be victims of an interpersonal wrongdoing they
had not forgiven. Interested individuals e-mailed the second author
who sent them the URL for the study website.
The study home page described the study’s purpose and goals
and then directed participants to a detailed questionnaire about un-
forgiven offenses. In addition to measures not relevant to the pres-
ent analysis, the questionnaire asked participants to recall an in-
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1107
terpersonal offense they had not forgiven and then answer a series
of questions designed to gather pertinent background information
concerning the episode recalled.
1
On average, participants took 1.5
hrs to complete the questionnaire.
MATERIALS
Participants were instructed to “Please recall a situation where you
were hurt, harmed, upset, angered, or offended by someone you
have not been able to forgive.” Instructions encouraged participants
to choose an especially important or memorable event and describe
it in two or three sentences. Participants were free to interpret the
term forgive themselves.
After completing the offense description, participants responded
to a second open-ended question soliciting explanations for their
inability/unwillingness to forgive (“Why were you not able/not
willing to forgive the offender?”). They then reported how much
time (in months and years) had passed since the event they recalled
occurred and rated (a) the vividness of their memory for this event
(1 “very little” to 7 “incredibly memorable”) and (b) how hurtful
it had been” (1 “not at all” and 7 “extremely hurtful”). The ques-
tionnaire also asked participants to indicate their relationship to the
offender and the offender’s sex. A technical error resulted in the
loss of responses to these two items. Fortunately, we were able to
infer this information from participants’ offense descriptions in the
majority of cases (93.5% and 78.5% of cases for type of offender and
offender sex, respectively).
To assess the extent to which participants were unwilling/unable
to forgive the particular offenses they recalled, we asked them to
respond to the questions “If, with some time and distance, you were
able to come to terms with or gain a better understanding of what
happened, what do you think is the likelihood that you would be
willing or able to forgive the person(s) who hurt you?” (1 “not at
all likely” to 7 “very likely”) and “Currently, I am _______ being
able/willing to forgiven the person(s) who hurt me” (1 “no where
near (or very far away from”) and 7 “very close to”). We computed
1. Due to technical difﬁculties with the website, ten participants completed the
questionnaire via paper and pencil.
1108 RAPSKE ET AL.
a mean preparedness to forgive score by averaging these two items
(alpha = .85).
Finally, participants responded to the open-ended questions
“What do you see as the advantages/beneﬁts of not forgiving?”
and “What do you see as the disadvantages/costs of not forgiv-
ing?” They then indicated how long (in months and years) they had
known the offender(s) at the time of the offense and whether their
offenders were currently involved in their lives.
CODING
We employed both inductive and deductive techniques to identify
themes in participants’ answers to our open-ended questions (e.g.,
Fereday & Muir-Cochrane, 2006). First, the second author gener-
ated a preliminary set of coding categories based on a review of the
forgiveness literature. The resulting taxonomy incorporated themes
discussed in reports of empirical investigations on topics relevant
to our research questions as well as theoretical treatments of the
barriers that hinder forgiveness (i.e., grudge theory). The ﬁrst and
second authors then inspected participants’ responses (indepen-
dently) to identify additional themes absent from this initial coding
scheme. Where they agreed on such a theme, they added it to the
classiﬁcation system.
This dual mode of coding had the advantage of permitting us
to capitalize on relevant themes in the existing literature while si-
multaneously enabling us to capture the full breadth and richness
of participants’ responses, particularly when these responses con-
tained novel themes. Given the paucity of research on unforgiven
offenses per se as well as variation in the scholarly attention de-
voted to the different research questions we explored, this approach
seemed particularly well-suited to the goals of our analysis. The
forgiveness literature offers very little direction, for example, con-
cerning the kinds of things people may construe as the advantages
and disadvantages of withholding forgiveness. In contrast, despite
the fact that few investigations have speciﬁcally targeted unfor-
given offenses, the literature nevertheless provides a comparatively
good sense of some of the kinds of justiﬁcations people may use to
explain their inability/unwillingness to forgive. Finally, although
we found some references to unforgivable offenses in our review
of the literature, the distinction between unforgiven and unforgiv-
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1109
able offenses (the former being the focus of the present research)
has thus far escaped forgiveness scholars’ attention and thus most
discussions of wrongdoings that cannot be forgiven focus on rare,
extreme, and often criminal acts.
In sum, as our goals in conducting this research involved extend-
ing existing knowledge, it seemed important to us to employ cod-
ing procedures that enabled us to acknowledge the contributions
of previous research and theorizing (hence our decision to employ
a taxonomy generated from the literature as the initial framework
of our coding scheme) while also attending to the novel and some-
times unexpected themes our participants voiced in their responses
(hence our decision to use inductive coding to enrich and elaborate
the initial coding scheme to reﬂect the depth and richness of our
data). Had we used a fully inductive approach to coding we might
have missed themes expressed infrequently by our participants
but which have been documented in the literature (e.g., the notion
that an offender’s intent to harm serves as a barrier to forgiveness).
Had we used a fully deductive approach to coding we would have
missed those themes participants mentioned but which, for one rea-
son or another, have not yet been discussed in the published for-
giveness literature.
To generate the preliminary taxonomy for coding descriptions of
the unforgiven offenses, we borrowed heavily from categories used
in studies of hurtful messages (Vangelisti, 1999; Vangelisti, Young,
Carpenter-Theune, & Alexander, 2005), hurt feelings (Feeney, 2004;
Leary, Springer, Negel, Ansell, & Evans, 1998), relational transgres-
sions (Metts & Cupach, 2007), and revenge (Yoshimura, 2002). To
categorize participants’ explanations for why they had not forgiven,
we constructed categories to reﬂect forgiveness-based explanations
identiﬁed in the literature (including the offender’s failure to per-
form appropriate reparative work, the possibility that the partici-
pant might view either the offense or the offender as unforgivable,
the individual’s view of what it means to forgive, and perceptions
that the offender’s actions were intentional), as well as the intensity
of emotion the victim experienced (i.e., the severity of the offense as
evident in the degree of emotional distress it caused at the time it oc-
curred or the extent of its impact on the participant’s life), enduring
suffering (i.e., the participants’ failure to recover from the offense),
the violation of relationship rules or roles, the participant’s failure to
achieve closure with respect to the motives and causes underlying
1110 RAPSKE ET AL.
the offender’s actions, and references to repeated offenses. Based on
grudge theory, we generated categories for the advantages of not
forgiving to represent the possibilities that participants might be-
lieve that withholding forgiveness could protect them from future
harm and that maintaining their role as victims would provide ben-
eﬁts such as enabling them to maintain a sense of their innocence,
dignity, or integrity, assert personal power in relation to the offend-
er, prevent them from forgetting valuable lessons they had learned
from the offense experience, and free them to take revenge. Finally,
based on grudge theory and research on the health-forgiveness link,
we constructed categories for the disadvantages of not forgiving to
reﬂect the possibility that participants might believe that withhold-
ing forgiveness could cause harm to their physical, emotional, or
psychological wellbeing (including leaving them vulnerable to con-
tinuing negative affect) and/or compromise their ability to form or
maintain interpersonal relationships.
Two independent coders (the third and fourth authors) coded
each participant’s responses to the four open-ended questions af-
ter being trained in the use of the coding scheme using responses
from 66 (35%) participants selected at random. Coders ﬁrst met to
identify those elements within responses that contained content
pertaining to the speciﬁc parameters under investigation. Calcu-
lated across the 185 participants’ responses, interrater agreement
was 90% (disagreements were resolved via discussion). Next coders
classiﬁed elements into categories based on the coding scheme. Us-
ing Krippendorff’s alpha to correct for chance agreement (Krippen-
dorff, 2009) and calculating across the full set of 185 participants,
interrater agreement was acceptable to excellent (mean alphas of
.88, .86, .86, and .97 for offenses, explanations, advantages, and
disadvantages, respectively) for all but a handful of rarely applied
codes (for explanations: .66 for “power” and .55 for “damaged vic-
tim’s self-concept/face;” for advantages: .32 for “views of forgive-
ness” and .49 for “correction/deterrence;” for disadvantages: .66 for
“lost opportunities” and .39 for “morally wrong”). We report the
frequencies for all codes. Frequencies for codes with low reliabili-
ties should nevertheless be considered with caution. Disagreements
were resolved via discussion.

RESULTS
Considerable time had passed since the incidents participants re-
called had occurred (M = 44.67 months, SD = 55.86). Nevertheless,
participants reported very vivid memories of the unforgiven epi-
sodes they described (M = 6.05, SD = 1.07), rated the offenses they
experienced as very hurtful in nature (M = 6.35, SD = 0.88) and, on
average, reported at best a moderate inclination to forgive their of-
fenders now or in the future (M = 3.66, SD = 1.86).
2
Friends (32.4%), romantic partners (24.3%), and family members
(12.9%) were the most common unforgiven offenders (just 5.9% were
strangers). Male offenders (44.3%) outnumbered females (32.4%)
and mixed-sex groups (1.6%). Excluding the data for 18 partici-
pants who reported having known their offenders for 0 months and
one participant who did not respond to this item, participants had
known their offenders for an average of 71.7 months (SD = 83.06) at
the time of the offense. Most (71.5% of those who knew their offend-
ers) were no longer involved with their offenders.
WHAT DO PEOPLE REPORT WHEN ASKED TO DESCRIBE
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES?
Our ﬁrst research question sought to expand our understanding of
the nature and scope of unforgiven offenses. To address this goal,
2. We conducted a series of t-tests on the demographic and offense context variables
to determine whether males and females differed on these key background variables.
Importantly, we found no evidence that such differences exist: None of the t-tests we
performed for sex of participant attained or even approached signiﬁcance (all p’s ≥
.19; full results of these analyses available from the second author upon request). This
pattern of results suggests that, despite the considerable disparity in the number of
males and females who completed our questionnaire, our samples of men and women
and their experiences in relation to their unforgiven offenses were sufﬁciently similar
to justify collapsing across sex in our content analysis of responses to the open-ended
questions. Most important, men and women differed in neither how hurtful they
rated the unforgiven offenses they recalled (males M = 6.18, SD = 0.80 vs. females
M = 6.38, SD = 0.89, t(1,182) = -.97, p = .33) nor their level of preparedness to forgive
their offenders at the time of the study (males M = 3.32, SD = 2.08 vs. females M =
3.71, SD = 1.83, t(1,181) = -.93, p = .35). Notwithstanding our failure to ﬁnd signiﬁcant
sex differences, we recognize that the number of men in our sample is very small.
Accordingly, any conclusions we draw about sex differences (or the lack thereof) on
the basis of this sample are best viewed with caution. Future research should strive for
more balanced samples.

WHAT EXPLANATIONS DO PEOPLE OFFER TO JUSTIFY THEIR
INABILITY/UNWILLINGNESS TO FORGIVE?
Our second research question explored the reasons participants
gave to explain the fact that they had not forgiven those responsible
for harming them in the incidents they recalled. Coders classiﬁed
participants’ explanations into one or more of 12 content categories
(see Table 2).
Most common by a considerable margin were explanations that
invoked themes related to forgiveness, particularly explanations
that attributed the participants’ inability or unwillingness to forgive
to the offender’s failure to perform reparative work. Participants
indicated that they withheld forgiveness because, for example, their
offenders denied having done anything wrong, acted as if they were
right, failed to apologize, showed no remorse, or failed to bring the
hurtful behavior to an end. In addition, a small minority of partici-
pants explained their inability/unwillingness to forgive by stating
categorically that either the offense or the offender was unforgiv-
able. For example, a female participant whose boyfriend cheated
on her with a schoolmate asserted that she had “always ruled that
cheating cannot be forgiven” (here and throughout, emphasis add-
ed).
Rare but nevertheless interesting were responses that hinged on
understandings of forgiveness that conﬂated forgiving with other
constructs such as condoning and pardoning. For instance, a female
participant argued that forgiving would “ . . . suggest that the act was
less wrong or harmful than it was.” Participants also justiﬁed with-
holding forgiveness with perspectives that called into question the
moral value of forgiving (e.g., “If I were to forgive I would feel that
I was betraying my mother”) and that equated forgiving with reconcil-
ing (e.g., “Forgiving him would mean that I’d have to stay as a friend
or probably as his girlfriend”).
The words of a female participant whose friend seduced her boy-
friend exemplify the central theme captured by explanations clas-
siﬁed in the next most common category. “She does not deserve
1114 RAPSKE ET AL.
my forgiveness,” she wrote, “because she was a friend of mine and
friends do not treat each other this way.” Inherent here and in other
participants’ responses in this category is the belief that friends
(and other close relationship partners) are held to higher standards
than strangers and that a failure to live up to these standards con-
stitutes grounds for withholding forgiveness (e.g., “. . . she should
know better than to behave as she did because she was my friend”). In
parallel fashion, some participants implied that their offenders’ be-
havior was inappropriate and uncalled for—and thus unworthy of
forgiveness—because they, themselves, had always met those stan-
dards (e.g., “I was always there for her”). Issues of trust and betrayal
also featured prominently in responses classiﬁed in this category
(e.g., “. . . I trusted her implicitly and could not believe someone who
I considered to be such a good friend could betray me so horribly”).

proached the questions we posed from a broader angle that also
considered the possible costs and beneﬁts of withholding forgive-
ness more generally. Coders classiﬁed participants’ responses to the
questions about advantages and disadvantages into one or more of
12 and 10 content categories, respectively (see Tables 3 and 4). More
than half of participants (N = 101 or 54.6%) identiﬁed both advan-
tages and disadvantages of withholding forgiveness.
Advantages. Nearly 30% of participants answered the question
asking them to identify the advantages of withholding forgiveness
by asserting that there were, in fact, no such advantages. No other
category of response was observed as frequently in participants’ re-
sponses.
3
The next most common class of response, observed in approxi-
mately one-quarter of participants’ answers, suggested that with-
holding forgiveness served (or serves) a self-protective function.
Participants claimed, for example, that withholding forgiveness en-
abled them to avoid unwanted contact with their offenders and/or
prevent further victimization at the hands of those who had harmed
them. Some asserted that not forgiving would protect them from
future victimization by others (e.g., “Makes me more cautious of who
I trust which would decrease the likelihood of being hurt again”).
Two additional themes were identiﬁed in at least 10% of partici-
pants’ responses. The ﬁrst captures the viewpoint that refusing to
forgive is a way to get even with the offender and thereby to reap
the beneﬁts of revenge. The majority of responses classiﬁed in this
category reﬂected the belief that withholding forgiveness serves to
educate the offender concerning the morally distasteful nature of
his or her behavior and its adverse impact on the participant (or
others). As a female participant put it, “By not forgiving . . . they will
hopefully realize the effects of what they did.” Other responses classiﬁed
within this category suggested that withholding forgiveness could
restore justice by essentially giving the offender a taste of his or her
own medicine (e.g., “it will hurt them if they think about it”) and, in
two instances, that withholding forgiveness could serve a deterrent
function (e.g., “It lets the offenders know that they have done some-

The last advantage to appear with any frequency in participants’

the process by which individuals move on with their lives after the

Disadvantages. The most common category of response to the ques-
tion about the disadvantages of withholding forgiveness revolved
around claims that holding a grudge—that is, not forgiving—is
physically and/or psychologically unhealthy. Identiﬁed in more
than half of all participants’ responses, such claims outnumbered
the next most frequent category of disadvantage by a considerable
margin and provide the only instance in which a single theme dom-
inated participants’ responses to one of the four open-ended ques-
tions we posed.
Some participants were rather vague in describing the harm-
ful nature of grudge holding (e.g., “it’s probably not good to hold
a grudge”). Others described the process of holding a grudge as
stressful and draining, sometimes suggesting a causal link between
the experience of grudge-induced stress and psychological or phys-
ical health and wellbeing (e.g., “sometimes quite stressful and this can
cause some damage to my health”).
Participants also discussed how withholding forgiveness did
nothing to diminish the suffering the offense caused or to end their
preoccupation with the offense (e.g., “the event keeps playing over
and over in my mind”). In other words, they argued that withhold-
ing forgiveness failed to achieve the goals they had hoped it would.
In addition, they identiﬁed a range of negative emotions such as
sadness, self-pity, anxiety, pain, anger, resentment, bitterness, frus-
tration, guilt, and remorse that resulted (or could result) from not
forgiving. Some bemoaned the fact that holding a grudge prevented
them from achieving a sense of closure with respect to the offense.
Responses describing negative relational consequences were
next most common in participants’ accounts. The majority of re-
sponses in this category could be further classiﬁed into one of two
subcategories: explanations focusing on consequences for existing

relationships and explanations focusing on consequences for new
relationships. Participants wrote, for example, that withholding for-

relationship with my sister will never be the same again”), or resulted
in the loss of these relationships. In addition, participants discussed
how failing to forgive made it (or may make it) more difﬁcult to
form new relationships (e.g., “not letting those walls come down for

DISCUSSION
UNFORGIVEN OFFENSES
Our ﬁrst research question sought to expand our understanding of
the nature and scope of unforgiven offenses. Two related conclu-
sions seem warranted on the basis of our analysis. First, our results
suggest that people can experience barriers that impede movement
toward forgiveness in response to wrongdoings of nearly any kind.
No one class of offense or injury constituted the typical unforgiven
offense in this study. Rather, the most commonly reported category
of unforgiven offense (betrayal) appeared in just over 30% of of-
fense descriptions and the majority appeared in less than 10%.
Second, unforgiven offenses may differ widely in severity. At the
extreme end of the continuum, small but noteworthy numbers of
participants reported on experiences of sexual assault, physical vio-
lence, and instances of abuse—the severe, criminal types of offenses
that have been identiﬁed as unforgivable in previous research (Ma-
4. Three (10.3%) of participants who initially asserted that there were no
disadvantages to withholding forgiveness went on to describe hypothetical
disadvantages, leaving 14.1% of our full sample responding to the question about
disadvantages by denying their existence.
1120 RAPSKE ET AL.
caskill, 2005a; Younger et al., 2004). But participants also reported
that they had not forgiven acts of considerably lesser apparent se-
verity and impact including, for instance, acts conveying an offend-
er’s indifference toward the participant’s stated needs or wishes,
teasing and other mild forms of hurtful communication, and subtle
efforts on an offender’s part to dissociate him or herself from the
participant. Accordingly, although our ﬁndings corroborate existing
research and theorizing suggesting that people consider some types
of offenses exceedingly difﬁcult—perhaps even impossible—to for-
give, they also indicate the existence of considerable variability in
what individuals are able and/or willing to forgive even among the
more mundane kinds of wrongdoings people encounter everyday.
Importantly, if we had hoped the present analysis would offer
insights into the features that distinguish forgiven offenses from
unforgiven offenses, the variability in participants’ offense descrip-
tions would certainly seem to frustrate that goal. We can learn little
from our analysis of the offenses, themselves, that speaks to the is-
sue of what (if anything) sets those wrongdoings people forgive
apart from those they do not. Although the validity of the follow-
ing speculation awaits investigation, what we think our ﬁndings
do suggest is that the answer may lay—not in the characteristics
of the offense per se—but at least in part in important individual
differences in people’s forgiveness thresholds. People may differ,
for example, in their judgments concerning the kinds of misdeeds
that do and do not merit forgiveness. We saw evidence of this when
some participants explicitly identiﬁed extra-dyadic involvement as
unforgivable, whereas others reporting on the same offense did not.
People may also differ in the height of their thresholds, with some
possessing relatively low thresholds such that even mild offenses
cross the line from forgivable to unforgivable in their minds, where-
as others tolerate greater injury or offense before ﬁnding themselves
unable or unwilling to forgive. Consistent with this latter possibility,
the discrepancy between the mean self-reported hurtfulness rating
(6.35 on a 7-point scale) and the mild to moderate apparent severity
of most participants’ offenses suggests that some people experience
even mild or moderately severe offenses as very hurtful and, there-
fore, as exceeding their forgiveness thresholds.
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1121
EXPLANATIONS FOR WITHHOLDING FORGIVENESS
With respect to our second research question, participants appealed
to a wide variety of explanations to account for the fact that they
had not forgiven those responsible for causing them harm in the
incidents they described. Viewed at one level, it is clear that many
of these explanations touched upon the central themes identiﬁed in
our review of the literature on unforgiven/difﬁcult to forgive of-
fenses (Baumeister et al., 1998; Exline & Baumeister, 2001; William-
son & Gonzales, 2007; Younger et al., 2004). For example, partici-
pants routinely attributed their failure to forgive to characteristics
of the offense (e.g., offense severity, whether it was a repeat offense,
whether it violated relationship rules, etc.) and the offender (e.g.,
whether he or she acted intentionally, his or her moral character),
identiﬁed barriers to forgiveness such as lingering feelings of hurt
and anger, and appealed to the forgiveness process and what it en-
tails (e.g., repentance, apologies, expressions of remorse) to explain
why they could not (or would not) forgive.
Viewed at a deeper level, however, it seems equally clear—and
more theoretically interesting—that participants’ explanations of-
ten rested on important assumptions concerning the nature and the
process of forgiveness. Most common among accounts of this sort
were explanations based on the offender’s failure to perform appro-
priate reparative work, accounts that usually attributed the partici-
pants’ inability or unwillingness to forgive to the offender’s failure
to apologize and/or express remorse.
Our ﬁndings here are congruent with other research suggesting
that people often view forgiveness as contingent on the satisfac-
tion of certain conditions (e.g., Friesen & Fletcher, 2007; Kanz, 2000;
Kearns & Fincham, 2004; Macaskill, 2005a; Younger et al., 2004). In-
deed, our ﬁndings suggest that people often feel completely justi-
ﬁed in withholding forgiveness when such conditions have not been
met. It is worth noting, however, that participants’ accounts placed
little emphasis on the prerequisite changes Macaskill’s participants
identiﬁed as relevant to those occupying the victim role (i.e., achiev-
ing closure, a willingness to compromise). Instead, explanations fo-
cused disproportionately on the offender’s actions in the wake of
the offense and the extent to which these actions conveyed an un-
repentant attitude. Not surprisingly, this pattern of results suggests
that wronged individuals are much more concerned with whether
1122 RAPSKE ET AL.
their offenders have demonstrated the contrite heart necessary to
deserve forgiveness than with whether they have themselves per-
formed the necessary emotional and cognitive work to forgive.
Explanations hinging on the offender having violated important
relationship rules—the second most frequently identiﬁed class of
explanation—might also be construed as closely connected to par-
ticipants’ conceptualizations of forgiveness. Explanations of this
sort, however, differ from the other forgiveness-based explanations
participants advanced by calling attention to the offender’s special
status in participants’ lives. As discussed previously, the ﬁnding that
some participants justiﬁed their inability or unwillingness to forgive
by stressing the privileged nature of their relationship with their of-
fenders suggests that people may often hold close relationship part-
ners to higher behavioral standards than strangers. For participants
who justiﬁed their failure to forgive in this way, it was as if certain
offenses become unforgiveable when committed by a friend. The
place an offender holds in an individual’s life may thus serve as an
important determinant of the individual’s forgiveness threshold in a
given situation. This possibility warrants further investigation.
NOT FORGIVING: PERCEIVED COSTS AND BENEFITS
Our ﬁnal research question examined individuals’ reﬂections on
the costs and beneﬁts associated with holding a grudge. Consistent
with one of the main propositions of grudge theory (Baumeister et
al., 1998; Exline & Baumeister, 2001), participants identiﬁed both
advantages and disadvantages of withholding forgiveness. In fact,
more than half provided examples of each.
Grudge theory proposes that withholding forgiveness offers vic-
tims two main beneﬁts: a measure of protection against future vic-
timization and the freedom to continue reaping the beneﬁts associ-
ated with the victim role. Congruent with the former proposition,
about a quarter of our sample ascribed a self-protective function to
grudge holding. Congruent with the latter, more than 10% of our
sample asserted that not forgiving gave them the license to take re-
venge against their offenders and thereby enjoy the rewards associ-
ated with repaying harm with harm.
Considerably more striking than the degree of correspondence
between participants’ responses and the advantages grudge theory
describes, however, was the general lack of consensus among par-
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1123
ticipants concerning the beneﬁts they perceived. The single most
common answer to the question we posed actually cast doubt on
the very existence of such beneﬁts and none of the beneﬁts partici-
pants did identify was observed in more than 25.4% of accounts. In-
stead, all but three categories of beneﬁts were mentioned by fewer
than 10% of our sample.
How many of these less common advantages would be validated
in future research remains an empirical question. Nevertheless, the
substantial diversity of response we observed suggests that people
may perceive a wide array of ways in which withholding forgive-
ness can be adaptive. Beyond protecting them from harm and in
addition to permitting them to beneﬁt from their status as victims,
our participants asserted, for example, that withholding forgiveness
enables them to stand ﬁrm in their convictions that an offender’s
behavior was wrong, facilitates the process of moving on with their
lives, prevents further conﬂict and confrontation with their offend-
ers, and reduces stress.
The fact that nearly 30% of our participants responded to our
query concerning the advantages of not forgiving with statements
indicating that they perceived no such advantages is also interest-
ing. Many participants seemed oblivious to the irony in withhold-
ing forgiveness in the absence of any rewards for doing so. Others
seemed aware of this irony, yet justiﬁed their continuing resentment
and feelings of ill will by implying that forgiveness was impossible
in the case at hand. For example, one participant commented that “I
don’t think there are any [advantages to not forgiving] but it is one
thing to forgive and another to actually truly forgive without lying
to myself.” Another wrote, “I don’t really see any [advantages to
not forgiving]...but at some point there are things not worth forgiv-
ing.” Such resistance to forgiving in the absence of perceptions that
there are beneﬁts to maintaining an unforgiving stance deserves at-
tention in future research.
Finally, given the considerable emphasis participants placed on
barriers to forgiveness in explaining their failure to forgive their of-
fenders, it may be worth noting that a small number of participants
discussed the advantages associated with not forgiving in terms
that once again underscore the “problems” with forgiving (e.g., that
forgiving is difﬁcult, time-consuming, or risky; that to forgive is to
condone or excuse the offender’s behavior). That is, some partici-
pants viewed avoiding the potential pitfalls associated with a chari-
table response to an offense as an advantage of not forgiving. This
1124 RAPSKE ET AL.
ﬁnding bolsters our claim that people’s conceptualizations of for-
giveness may sometimes impede movement toward forgiveness.
In contrast to ﬁndings for the perceived beneﬁts of withholding
forgiveness where diversity of response was the rule, participants
demonstrated considerable agreement concerning its key disadvan-
tage. Admittedly, they described a range of other undesirable conse-
quences as well, but the belief that holding a grudge is “unhealthy”
was identiﬁed in more than half of all participants’ responses and
dominated the other categories of disadvantages by a margin of
nearly two to one.
Prior research provides some basis for believing that partici-
pants are correct in viewing withholding forgiveness as potentially
harmful to their health and wellbeing. The link between anger and
hostility—two emotions central to the experience of unforgiveness
(Worthington, 2001)—and negative health consequences (Barefoot
et al., 1983; Siegel, 1992) has been well documented, for example,
and research generally supports the view that forgiving is positively
associated with physical and psychological wellness (e.g., Bono et
al., 2008; Lawler-Row et al., 2008; Witvliet et al., 2001). In addition,
theoretical treatments of grudge holding posit that one of the major
drawbacks associated with holding a grudge is continuing negative
affect (Baumeister et al., 1998; Exline & Baumeister, 2001).
The present results do more than just mirror ﬁndings from past
research, however. Because we asked participants to reﬂect on both
the advantages and the disadvantages associated with not forgiv-
ing, our results highlight potential contradictions in participants’
thinking about the consequences associated with holding a grudge.
For example, participants seem to believe that withholding forgive-
ness can both reduce the unpleasant emotional consequences as-
sociated with an offense and contribute to their persistence over
time, facilitate moving on with life or trap the victim in a pattern of
rumination and lingering distress, allow the victim to maintain his
or her dignity and integrity or engender feelings of guilt and moral
wrongdoing, protect the self from future confrontation or open the
self to future harm. Our results thus suggest that understanding
how individuals reconcile awareness of the real or potential costs
to health and wellbeing that accompany withholding of forgiveness
with their views concerning its main beneﬁts should be a major fo-
cus of investigation. How do people weigh the various perceived
beneﬁts and costs to determine whether a change in course of ac-
tion is required? Do these weights vary over time or with changing
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1125
circumstances? What degree of imbalance between cost and reward
will people tolerate before seeking to restore such balance?
In addition to continuing negative affect, grudge theory identiﬁes
reduced interpersonal functioning as a possible downside to main-
taining the victim role in the aftermath of an offense. There was con-
siderable evidence in the present study that participants believed
they had experienced such reduced functioning as a result of their
inability or unwillingness to forgive. Indeed, responses suggesting
that relationships suffer when people fail to forgive were second
in frequency only to responses predicated on negative health con-
sequences. Participants’ concern with how their relationships with
their offenders have deteriorated as a result of withholding forgive-
ness corroborates ﬁndings from other research which suggest that
unforgiveness is incompatible with relational closeness and intima-
cy (e.g., Baumeister et al., 1998; Karremans, Van Lange, Ouwerkerk,
& Kluwer, 2003). To our knowledge, however, researchers have not
yet explored the possibility that not forgiving might have implica-
tions for people’s relationships with persons other than the offender
and/or for the formation of new relationships. The present results
thus point to a new domain of inquiry worthy of researchers’ atten-
tion.
They also point to the need for further expansion of grudge the-
ory as far as its consideration of the possible costs associated with
grudge holding is concerned. Whether the less common disad-
vantages participants reported will be validated in future research
awaits investigation. Nevertheless, the diversity of response we ob-
served suggests that people may believe that a wide array of costs
can accompany not forgiving. Beyond continuing negative affect
and in addition to its deleterious effects on interpersonal function-
ing, our participants claimed, for example, that holding a grudge
caused undesirable changes in their character, elicited feelings of
guilt or wrongdoing, made it more difﬁcult to forgive in the future,
backﬁred in the sense that it hurt them and not their offenders, and
resulted in lost opportunities.
Finally, when asked to discuss the disadvantages of not forgiving,
roughly 15% of our sample responded with explicit statements that
no such disadvantages exist. This ﬁnding is intriguing in light of the
literature’s general tendency to idealize forgiveness as a response to
wrongdoing (cf., Macaskill, 2005b; Murphy, 2005). If future research
substantiates participants’ claims that maintaining feelings of ill
will toward an offender has cost them nothing—even if it proved
1126 RAPSKE ET AL.
that the particular circumstances under which this held true were
generally rare—it would call into question current assumptions that
withholding forgiveness is an inherently suboptimal approach to
dealing with the fallout of interpersonal injury or offense.
LIMITATIONS AND DIRECTIONS FOR FUTURE RESEARCH
Several limitations of the present research are worthy of note. First,
females greatly outnumbered males in our sample and all partici-
pants were undergraduates. It will be important to recruit other,
less homogenous samples in the future.
Second, although we instructed participants to recall a time they
were unable to forgive, it was clear from their responses that there
was meaningful variation in the extent to which the fact that they
had not forgiven was the product of some limit to their capacities
to forgive (reﬂecting an inability to forgive) rather than the result
of deliberate choice (reﬂecting an unwillingness to forgive). Unfor-
tunately, participants’ status on this variable could not be inferred
in enough cases to permit comparisons between groups. As the
dispositions, attitudes, and experiences of persons who are unable
to forgive may differ in nontrivial ways from the those of persons
who are unwilling to forgive, our understanding of the processes
by which people negotiate the fallout of interpersonal offenses will
require that future research explore this distinction and its ramiﬁca-
tions in some depth.
Finally, much of what participants offered in their responses to
the questions we posed may constitute post hoc reasoning based on
popular conceptions of the kinds of factors that serve as stumbling
blocks to forgiveness and the sorts of costs and beneﬁts that might
accrue from a failure to forgive. Participants’ responses are thus
best considered their retrospective reﬂections on their unforgiven
offenses rather than veridical accounts of the events, processes,
and outcomes that actually occurred. Nevertheless, given the con-
siderable need for a deeper, more elaborated understanding of lay
conceptualizations of forgiveness (e.g., Younger et al., 2004; Zech-
meister & Romero, 2002), and in light of the possibility that popular
conceptions of forgiveness may play a ﬁgural role in determining
people’s orientations toward, expectations concerning, and perhaps
even their experiences of forgiveness, we think our ﬁndings con-
tribute to the literature in important ways.
UNFORGIVEN INTERPERSONAL OFFENSES 1127
IMPLICATIONS
Notwithstanding the limitations of this study and the clear need for
further research in this area, our ﬁndings have some potentially im-
portant implications for both theory and the design and implementa-
tion of forgiveness interventions. With respect to the former, the fact
that coders identiﬁed a diverse array of novel themes in participants’
responses to the questions asking them to explain their unwilling-
ness/inability to forgive and to reﬂect on the costs and beneﬁts as-
sociated with not forgiving demonstrates a need for further theoreti-
cal development on the experience of withholding forgiveness. We
would argue that the literature’s focus on forgiving to the exclusion
of other responses to wrongdoing has blinded many scholars to the
fact that people are not always willing or able to forgive. The new
codes that emerged during analysis of participants’ accounts of the
unforgiven offenses they recalled highlight some of the gaps in the
resulting literature. Among other things, these new categories call
for expansion of Baumeister and colleagues’ grudge theory and the
development of theories capable of explaining the origins and op-
eration of lay conceptualizations of forgiveness. More generally, our
ﬁndings suggest that there may be considerable theoretical value in
distinguishing unforgiven from unforgivable offenses and in articu-
lating those processes that determine when withholding forgiveness
reﬂects an unwillingness rather than an inability to forgive.
Our ﬁndings have several additional implications with respect to
forgiveness interventions. First, therapists should work to ensure
they and their clients share a common understanding of the pro-
cesses and outcomes involved in forgiving (cf., Wade, Johnson, &
Meyer, 2008). Not only do our ﬁndings add to the growing body of
literature which suggests that laypeople vary in the extent to which
they concur with scholarly understandings of what forgiveness is
and operate under the same assumptions scholars do concerning
the changes in motivation, attitude, behavior, and affect that for-
giving entails, they also suggest that people’s conceptualizations
of forgiveness may play a central role in accounting for failures to
forgive.
Second, before proceeding with any intervention, therapists
should adopt a critical perspective in determining whether forgive-
ness is truly appropriate for a given individual in a given instance
(cf., Wade et al, 2008). We agree with Macaskill (2005b) and Murphy
1128 RAPSKE ET AL.
(2005) who argue that scholars have been too quick to accept the no-
tion that forgiveness is a desirable, adaptive, constructive response
to nearly all acts of wrongdoing. Consistent with the main tenets
of grudge theory, our participants often offered what appeared to
be compelling reasons for withholding forgiveness and discussed
signiﬁcant costs that might attend a decision to forgive. They also
identiﬁed an array of beneﬁts associated with not forgiving. Even if
future research reveals such beneﬁts to be infrequent or more illu-
sory than real, we think therapists would be well advised to explore
the basis and the validity of their clients’ perspectives concerning
the costs and beneﬁts associated with withholding forgiveness be-
fore coming to a decision as to whether or not to advocate that their
clients pursue forgiveness. Such beliefs may provide a warrant for
considering alternative means of dealing with the distress their cli-
ents may continue to experience in the aftermath of the offense or
injury.
Finally, in the event that both therapist and client are persuaded
that seeking forgiveness is appropriate and desirable in the particu-
lar instance at hand, our results suggest that it might be possible to
use the client’s beliefs about the harmful side-effects of maintaining
an unforgiving stance toward past offenses as leverage in motivat-
ing him or her to engage in the work of forgiving. Almost 80% of
our participants described one or more (real or potential) costs ac-
companying the failure to forgive and fully half viewed withhold-
ing forgiveness as unhealthy. There may thus be substantial oppor-
tunity to capitalize on people’s conceptions of the drawbacks asso-
ciated with grudge holding and, together with strategies designed
to encourage a more critical examination of its advantages, facilitate
movement in the direction of forgiveness if and when such move-
ment is appropriate.
